iti92:1.1: This was said by the Buddha, the Perfected One: that is what I heard.
iti92:2.1: “Mendicants, suppose a mendicant were to hold the corner of my cloak and follow behind me step by step.
iti92:2.2: Yet they covet sensual pleasures; they’re infatuated, full of ill will and malicious intent. They are unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.
iti92:2.3: Then they are far from me, and I from them.
iti92:2.5: Because that mendicant does not see the teaching.
iti92:2.6: Not seeing the teaching, they do not see me.
iti92:3.1: Suppose a mendicant were to live a hundred leagues away.
iti92:3.2: Yet they do not covet sensual pleasures; they’re not infatuated, or full of ill will and malicious intent. They have established mindfulness, situational awareness and immersion, with unified mind and restrained faculties.
iti92:3.3: Then they are close to me, and I to them.
iti92:3.5: Because that mendicant sees the teaching.
iti92:3.6: Seeing the teaching, they see me.”
iti92:4.3: yet see how distant they are—
iti92:5.1: An astute person who has understood
iti92:5.4: like a lake unstirred by the wind.
iti92:7.1: This too is a matter that was spoken by the Blessed One: that is what I heard.
